column15: Notes
21 hedgehogs and 23 sugar gliders also seized. One arrest.

column2: Shingleback Lizards; bluetongue lizards; three Black-headed Pythons; albino Carpet Python
column15: 24 Shingleback Lizards, 16 bluetongue lizards, three Black-headed Pythons, and one albino Carpet Python (endangered - numbers may be as low as 100). One Australian man arrested.
Seized by UK Border Agency CITES team
Ploughshare tortoise is CITES I. was found concealed in the luggage of a businessman returning from China
One Ploughshare found in a shipment of tortoises. The Ploughshare had been previously seized ^ and was stolen from a conservation trust in Madagascar
Nine boxes arrived in Paris. Two labelled as Sahara Mastigures (CITES II). Illegal in Niger to export wild specimens of this species. The other seven were legal species.
Declared as Chinese Stripe Neck Turtles, discovered in the air freight export area. Chinese Box Turtles are CITES II

The two boxes of lizards, which is a protected species, were part of a batch of nine boxes; only 7 of the 9 cases had certificates authorizing the export of chameleons and reptiles, yellow or red lizards; this species is banned by CITES
27 Radiated Tortoises (CITES I) and 30 Leopard Tortoises (CITES II) concealed in personal luggage. One suspect arrested.
suspect arrested and sentenced after admitting to at least two other successful previous smuggling instances. The lizards were put in money belts fastened around the chest.
8 Radiated Tortoises, 22 Leopard Tortoises, and 116 birds of 13 species. One suspect arrested.

column14: Hidden in baggage and a "purpose-built body pack concealed in Kubus's underwear"
column15: The lizards were found in a hand-sewn pouch in his underwear. German national, Hans Kurt Kubus was sentenced and fined. Sticky-toed geckos are CITES III. 24 Sticky-toed geckos and 20 skinks were discovered. One was found during a baggage search, and the other 43 were discovered in the suspect's underwear. All the reptiles had been illegally collected from the wild. Kubus plead guilty to seven charges (two under the Wildlife Act and five CITES violations) and was convicted on all charges. He was sentenced to a fine of NZD5000 (usD3500), or NZD1000 per CITES violation, and 14 weeks' imprisonment

column13: "Two tons of fresh fruit" alerted customs to unusual activity
column15: Exported by a company identified as "IDT PD" located west of Jakarta; the two people in charge of the cargo were interviewed but could not immediately be suspects without further investigation

"A traveler arrested at Rochambeau airport. He carried with him protected frogs."; suspect is a German citizen of Greek origin and was monitored for "a few days"; frogs from Amazon basin; the frogs are colorful and toxic; suspect was arrested
Spur-thighed Tortoises (CITES II) found with prohibited plant material and food
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). One Malaysia-bound Indian national arrested. One source says seizure occurred on May 30, rather than May 24

column2: Radiated Tortoises; Kapikas; ploughshare tortoises; spider tortoises
column15: The animals were locked in two bags, which also contained drugs; 285 radiated tortoises, 14 kapika turltes, the pyxis arachnoid tortoises, angonoka tortule and a ploughshare tortoises (very rare); turtles are alive and were looking at being repatriated back to Madagascar; the three species of turtles are in Appendix I of CITES

column2: radiated tortoises; ploughshare tortoises; tomato frogs
column15: Four hundred Radiated Tortoises (CITES I), 11 Spider Tortoises, and four Ploughshare Tortoises. Two women were arrested and sentenced to a year in prison

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Pig-Nosed Turtles; White-Front Box Turtles
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II), White-front Box turtles (CITES I), Pig-Nosed Turtles (CITES II). One arrest and conviction. The trafficker claimed that he was paid by Atsushi Yamagami. This seizure spawned 'Operation Flying Turtle' by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to catch Yamagami and his smuggling ring.

The snakes got out of the luggage and were crawling on the carousel; suspect was Keng Liang Wong and he was arrested, not his first time trafficking as he has already served a sentence of 6 years in prison after being arrested in 1998 for smuggling protected reptile species; suspect nicknamed "Lizard King"
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) in four suitcases. Believed to have been destined for Bangkok's Chatuchak weekend market. One arrest-potentiallly a Pakistani national.
217 Radiated Tortoises and one Ploughshare found in two suitcases (all CITES I) on baggage claim
Additionally, 2 parrots and a squirrel were found with the snakes. Indonesian officials suspect assistance from airport security in Jakarta.

column2: Pig-Nosed Turtles; Star Tortoises; Chinese Soft-Shell Turtles; Indian Flap Turtles; Chinese Big-Headed Turtles; Snail Eating Turtles
column15: 15 Pig-Nosed Turtles (CITES II), 14 Snail Eating Turtles (CITES II), 3 Chinese Big-headed Turtles (CITES II), 5 Indian Flap Turtles (CITES II), Chinese Soft Shelled Turtles (CITES II), Star Tortoises (Either CITES I or CITES II) were discovered in 5 japanese candy packages, wrapped in cloth along with $16,112 of undeclared currency. Animals were recovered alive and two japanese nationals were arrested. This seizure was the culmination of 'Operation Flying Turtle' by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Singaporean man was arrested also carrying two Bali Myna birds and four slow lorises (CITES II). Pig-nosed turtles are listed as CITES I
The reptiles were bound for a German trader. Green tree pythons were among the specimens, many of which died after the seizure

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Ball Pythons; Elongated Tortoises; Bearded Dragons; Radiated Tortoises; Argentine Horned Frogs; Mata mata Turtles; Spiny Tailed Lizards; Striped Narrow-Headed Turtles; Aldabra Troiteses; Boa Constrictors; Sudan Plated Lizards; Corn Snakes; King Snakes; Ploughshare Toirtoises; Pig-nosed Turtles; milk snakes; hog-nosed snakes
column15: 88 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II), 34 Ball pythons (CITES II), 33 Elongated Tortoises(CITES II), 19 Bearded Dragons, 7 Radiated tortoises (CITES I), 6 Argentine Horned Frogs, 4 Mata Mata Turtles, 4 Spiny Tailed Lizards, 4 Striped Narrow-headed turtles (CITES II), 3 Aldabra Tortoises(CITES II), 2 Boa Constrictors (CITES I), 2 Sudan Plated Lizards, 2 Corn Snakes, 2 King Snakes, 1 Ploughshare Tortoise(CITES I), 1 Pig-nosed Turtle(CITES II), 1 Milk Snake, 1 Hog nosed Snake. Also found 22 common squirrels, 18 baboon spider and 1 African grey parrot. One arrest. The man had purchased all the animals at Chatuchak Market (An outdoor market in Bangkok). The animals were found in three suitcases

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Lizards; Pythons; Boa Constrictors; Ploughshare Tortoises; Yellow-headed turtles
column15: suspect aged 34 was about to bard the plane; 88 Indian star turtles, 33 yellow-headed turtle and ploughshare tortoise (very rare protected species), 2 boa constrictors, 34 pythons, 18 tarantulas, squirrels, several species of lizards and a Gray Gabon parrot; majority of the reptiles were neclosed in plastic boxes and others were founded in different compartments in suitcases; value estimated at 18,000 euros
Two arrests. The suspects were Kuwaiti nationals. Snakes were sedated and the suspects intended to sell the pythons to collectors in the UAE.
Reticulated Pythons (CITES II)
Spur-thighed Tortoises (CITES II)

column14: Pockets in wicker baskets; plastic bottles with leaves inside
column15: Total of 557 animals protected under Appendix II of CITES; 467 chameleons, 23 lizards and 58 frogs; 5 chameleons and 4 lizards found dead; Malagasy citizen (40 years old) was charged and charged with Customs fraud; trying to ship the animals to China
Part of an operation from the OCLAESP; 9 people were arrested

A wildlife expert identified five species through photos of the seizure: Sylheti Roof Turtle (CITES II), Spotted Pond Turtle (likely same as Black Pond Turtle, CITES I), Bengal-eyed turtle (CITES I), Asian Leaf Turtle (CITES II), and Shila Turtle (Black Pond Turtles, CITES I).

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Burmese Star Tortoises
column15: Indian and Burmese Star Tortoises (CITES II). Found in unclaimed bags. Loading tags suggested bags had originally come from Dhaka, Bangladesh before going to Japan via Bangkok, and then coming back to Bangkok to be collected. Four tortoises had died, they had been in the bags for about 10 days. Other sources say there were 400 turtles and other rare reptiles, including gavials (CITES I). Found in four suitcases on June 2, according to some sources. One source claims there were 35 star tortoises, and that the animals were found in suitcases at Suvarnabhumi Airport on the way to India.
Reticulated Pythons (CITES II)
Two Radiated Tortoises (CITES I), four Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II), three Bearded Dragons, and 10 unidentified frogs on a Chinese national bound for Hong Kong
Various species purchased at Chauhak Market. Iranian national arrested was already suspected of involvement in an animal smuggling ring
suspects were Indian and Malagasy, they were arrested; in Appendix I and II of CITES
Indian Star Tortoises are CITES II. Found in two unclaimed luggage bags. Repatriated to India in Dec 2011.
Wrapped in nylon bags stuffed in man's pants. suspect was charged under the Laceey act. 7 snnakes, 3 turtles
95 Boa constrictors, 2 rhinocerous vipers, 1 mata-mata turtle. Anson Wong Keng Liang was sentenced.
The suspect is an Australian man aged 22 who was returning to Munich from Syndy, he was arrested; the pythons were white and 30cm long on average, rare specimens

column14: Wrapped in baby diapers in small plastic baskets
column15: 92 baby turtles, 1 adult; name of Nivolalao (I think); during routine search
Eggs were turned over to U.S. fish and Wildlife Service and sent to undergo DNA analysis

75 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) and "Various snakes" found in the possession of an Indonesian woman returning from Bangkok. 28 tortoises died - 27 were already dead when she was stopped. 19 tortoises later repatriated to India. One source claims there were only 47 tortoises total.
Graceful Chameleons (CITES II)

10 Boa Constrictors, poisonous pit vipers, coral snakes, lizards and spiders. Animals were labeled by latin name in Various plastic containers, bags and socks. Several specimens died prior to discovery. A Czech national was arrested and charged. He is believed to be part of a larger smuggling ring due to his short stay in Argentina and the large number and variety of specimens from across South America; suspect named as Karel Abelovsky, 51
While species were unspecified, all were described as endangered. Eggs were turned over to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

Four boxes of pangolin scales (CITES II) and four boxes of shells from about 40 Green and Hawkville turtles (both CITES I). Boxes were signed by "Novelito Rendon", and were destined to be delivered to "Renato Aloyan" in Taboan, Cebu City
The permits required by CITES had been issues but the authorized for export quota was exceeded by 14 units in this case; a quarter of the animals are in poor health and 7 had already died

column13: The Kenyan Customs officers noticed that the two individuals walked funny
column15: The men are Malagasy nationals, the men were brought to trial 3 ays after the arrest; suspects said they were a wedding gift; they were fined by the court
Pig-Nosed Turtles (CITES II) in two suitcases
690 juveniles. Living turtles from this and previous ^ seizure were released into the wild. 218 of the turtles died in quarantine
Saltwater Crocodile (CITES II)

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Three-Keeled Turtles; Indian Roofed Turtles
column15: Two Indians arrested with 300 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II), 90 Three-Keeled Turtles, and 25 Indian Roofed Turtles. 115 different turtles allegedly found in two suitcases. 7 species total (Indian Star Tortoises, black turtle, tricarinate hill turtle, spotted pond turtle, crowned turtle, Sylheti roofed turtle and brown roofed turtle), potentially plus three-keeled turtles and Indian roofed turtles? Source is inconsistent. Tapan Kumar Dey, forest conservator at Wildlife Management and Nature Conservation Division, warned authorities about smuggling attempt.
112 chameleons, 72 snakes and 100 frogs; 3 of the snakes were very venomous; didn't say which CITES was violated
Indian Star Tortoises are CITES II. Concealed in gunny bags in the carry on. An Indian national was arrested.

Man said that the lizards were "for cooking"; to prove his good faith, the young man "was even prepared to tear the head with his teeth of the a spiny-tailed lizards before the agents"; man fined 1000 euros

column14: Six cloth bags of 50 tortoises each within a stroller bag
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) packaged in six cloth bags of 50 tortoises each within a stroller bag. Mohammad Rafiyudin tried to check-in on Sri Lanka Airlines flight UL132. Rafiyudin had arrived at the airport at 6:45 for a 9:45 flight -- a source suspected that he may have had an agreement with low-tier officials at the airport, and had come to check in early as a result. Rafiyudin and his accomplices had initially tried to transport creatures through Chennai, but changed their minds "as security was considered impenetrable". The tortoises were moved to Trichy by road, at which point Rafiyudin was to fly the tortoises from India to Kuala Lumpur via Colombo. Air "intelligence sources" had a vague idea that contraband would be checked in to Trichy airport, but had no other knowledge. They increased regular surveillance in anticipation regardless. Separately, airline security found the packages suspicious, and "soon it was referred to the Customs at the intervention of the Air Intelligence". Rafiyudin was arrested and charged. More reliable sources name the arrested individual as Ahamed Sirajudeen (47) from Chennai.
Galapagos Land Iguanas are CITES II. A German national was arrested and eventually sentenced
According to a Customs officer, these animals were going to be sold as pets

Tricarinate Hill Turtles(CITES I) discovered packed in two suitcases. Two men, one Indian and one Bangladeshi were arrested. Authorities were tipped off. The two men were arrested around 12:45 am as they were trying to board PG 746 (Bangkok Airways, flies from Dhaka to Bangkok). After the arrest, their luggage was searched, and 50 and 58 turtles were found wrapped in scotch tape in two bags. The luggage tags beared the name of an "Afsana" and listed her cellphone number. Officials found that a Civil Aviation Authority of Bangladesh (CAAB) security operator and assistant commissioner of Customs that were on duty at the airport had spoken to Afsana over her cellphone -- likely corruption. Police filed a case against the two men, the CAAB security operator, and the Customs assistant commissioner

column2: Ball Pythons; Color Morph Corn Snakes; Boa Constrictors
column15: Ball python (CITES II), 7 Boa Constrictors (CITES I), 19 Color morph corn snakes. Purchased at the National Reptile Breeders Expo in Daytona in August 2012. Snakes were hidden in stereo speakers checked as baggage. Snakes were inteded for use as commercial breeders. One arrest and conviction.

column14: Hidden in pillow cases and a suitcase
column15: Indian Star Tortoises are CITES II. An Indian national was arrested. The tortoises were discovered after a tip.

Air Intelligence Unit of Mumbai Customs officials frisked three men in Mumbai and found that one was wearing two pairs of underwear. He had stashed 10 turtles in between the layers of underwear. Some of the turtles were star turtles. Officials also found that all three were also carrying two Persian cats (six total), "three Tarantula spiders (known to be extremely poisonous), 11 eggs of unknown birds, and pigeon and fish foods from the trio's bags". They were fined Rs. 1.85 lakh and "sent back". Faizan Khan, who was caught with the turtles, allegedly told police he paid between Rs5,000 and Rs10,000 per pair for the turtles. Khan has a shop in Musfir Khana, Mumbai where he sells rare wildlife. Sheikh Naushad Mus planned to sell the Persian cats for Rs50,000. Mus allegedly purchased them in Bangkok for Rs20,000 each. Mus has a farm in Pune where he trades rare species. Khan, Mus, and Sheikh Nadir Ahmed are all Indian nationals. Customs officials reported that Ahmed was paid Rs10,000 and was given free tickets by Mus for his help. Mus and Khan apparently traveled to Bankok three times in 2012.

Thai national, along with two accomplices was arrested as he prepared to board a plane to Dubai; was a stowaway. He also had a loris and a lemur in his underwear. Another loris was found in the trash; "they left because they could not carry it" said a Customs agent. Names: Hamad Al-Dhaheri, Mohammed Al-Shamsi, and Rashid Al-Shamsi; were all arrested

569 or 570 baby Radiated Turtles (CITES I) were seized after a tip-off and two Indo-Pakistanis were arrested. The turtles were found in four suitcases. Three babies had already died and 10 were in poor condition. The passengers were on an Air Madagascar flight to "Bangkok, Thailand and Guangzhou, China". The two suspects were known locally as the "Karana".

Several hundred kilos of Bush meat seized, including antelope, pangolin, monkey, and crocodile; discovered in passenger luggage arriving from "Africa" by a morning flight; Customs operation lasted four hours; the Bushmeat was hidden at the bottom of the bags and suitcases; Bushmeat destined fro the African market Chateau-Rouge in Paris

column2: Three-Keeled Pond Turtles; Indian Pond Tortoises
column13: Security stopped them due to "suspicious behavior"
column15: Air Intelligence Unit of Mumbai Customs seized 47 Three-Keeled Pond Turtles (CITES III and IUCN Endangered List) and 10 Indian Pond Tortoises (CITES I) in the bags of Abdul Razzak Bashir Ahmad (55) and Ambur Mushtaquin (25). The suspects told the AIU that they were given the bags by someone outside the Chennai airport. Officials discovered that Ahmad made 8 trips to Bangkok this year, while Mushtaquin has made seven.

The turtles (unnamed) were listed as CITES II. The turtles were de-shelled and headless and packed with the beef in a styrofoam container. The passenger bringing them in fled. but was eventually caught and arrested.

column2: Shila Turtles; Kali Turtles; Star Turtles
column15: Shila Turtles (aka Tricarinate Hill Turtles, CITES I), Star Turtles (CITES II), and Kali Turtles (aka Black Pond Turtles, CITES I). The turtles were on their way to either Thailand or Singapore. Airport security discovered suspicious objects in luggage that was being scanned at Gate No. 3 aroung 11:00 am. Personnel asked the owner of the luggage to open the bag, but he said he had left the key outside and ran. Armed Police Battalion (APBn) chased him, but he was able to get on a "microbus". Officers got the bus to stop, but the man managed to get off and run. Officials arrested three people (Mohammad Yeasin, Mohammad Sabuj, and Mohammad Sohagh) from the bus, all of whom denied involvement in the smuggling attempt.
Various species of snake were shipped to Hong Kong in 203 boxes labeled as fruit, and were returned by Hong Kong authorities after discovery.
5 oriental rattlesnakes, 158 monocled cobras

H. Shamsudeen (47) and M. Mohammed Younis (67) were arrested trying to smuggle 27 fresh water tortoises out of India to Bangkok. Officials found them suspicious and stopped them before getting on their flight. 27 tortoises were found packed in their luggage, and because they did not have any authorization or clearance papers, they were arrested. One of the smugglers claimed that they had been in the textile business for 10 years, and would develop relationships with people who they would move packages for. Once a relationship was established, they would not under any circumstances check or open the package. They were allegedly offered 3000 baht to deliver the luggage to a black-shirted person waiting for them in Bangkok. They said they had been doing business in Malaysia and Bangkok.
Python (CITES I/II) and Monitor Lizard (CITES II)
The Hawksbill scutes were found in two suitcases brought in by two travellers. One arrest.
Argentine Teju (CITES II)

column2: Three-Keeled Turtles; Indian Spotted Turtles; Tortoises
column14: Wrapped in cloth and stuffed in a bag
column15: A security official with Mumbai International Airport Pvt Ltd noticed an object resembling a turtle while screening a checked bag at the airport. When he opened the bag, he found 97 turtles of different sizes wrapped in cloth and stuffed in a bag. The owner of the bag, Mohammed Arif (22), had already boarded flight TG 318 to Bangkok, but he was removed from the plane. Arif revealed that his friend Nasir gave him the bag. He claimed he had been paid $300 to take it to Bangkok

Ploughshare tortoises and Radiated Tortoises are both CITES I. The tortoises were registered to a woman but found in the possession of a Thai man previously arrested for wildlife trafficking. Royal Thai Customs authorities found him attempting to collect the bag containing the tortoises. Clara Rahantamalala (25) and O Visarnkol (38) were arrested.

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Black Pond Turtles
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) and Black Pond turtles (CITES I) were found in an unclaimed suitcase on the luggage carousel.
Pig-nosed Turtles (CITES I).

The turtles were discovered in three plastic bags in the passenger's luggage as he attempted to exit Customs. The Indian passenger was fined. The indian government sent the turtles to a private clinic, where all but 800 died.

2 Asian reticulated pythons(CITES II), 2 Green tree pythons (CITES II), 2 blue malaysian coral snakes, 4 flying squirrels. Pythons were packed in plastic boxes with airholes. coral snakes were in cardboard boxes with grass. One arrest
320 Black Spotted Turtles (CITES I). Turtles were concealed in clothing in passenger's bag. Another source said the turtles were "packed in a carton". Ahmed Faraz was arrested.

A Mumbai International Airport Pvt Ltd (MIAL) official scanning a checked bag noticed suspicious objects inside the bag. The official opened the bag and found 385 tortoises inside. The Chinese national who owned the bag was arrested before she was able to board her Cathay Pacific flight to Hong Kong. The woman claimed the bag was handed to her by a friend in Mumbai.

column13: Airport police approached the suspects as a result of their suspicious behavior
column14: Inside white packets in a sack
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). All tortoises were alive. Two arrests. The suspects were also found with ornamental fish. Police on patrol at the airport became suspicious when they saw two men walking towards the cargo complex with a sack around 4 am. When the men weren't able to answer their questions, the officers took them to the NSCBI airport police station, where they opened the sack. The officers found goldfish in plastic bags and white packets containing 21 star tortoises (6 female, 15 male). The suspects, Tapas Basak and Md Irfan said they were supposed to be shipped on a Spice Jet flight to Chennai.

Carrying out a routine check, 40 turtles, 39 chameleons and an unknown number of frogs were about to be shipped; found during a routine check; tried to find owner of luggage but couldn't--all passengers were already on board, so the suspect likely got away

column2: Utila Spiny-Tailed Iguanas; Horned Lizards; Desert Tortoises; Spotted Box Turtles
column15: 7 utila spiny-tailed iguana (CITES II), 6 spotted box turtles (CITES II), 19 desert tortoises (CITES II), 4 horned lizards. Japanese citizen was arrested. Shipment was detected because she had a previous trafficking arrest.

Two smugglers based in Chennai, India were caught. The red-eared sliders (native to the Americas) were in three bags, and were smuggled from China to India via Singapore. A passenger noticed a cross on one of the bags when the bags were on a conveyor belt and informed Customs officials. Red-eared sliders are not a protected or endangered species, but they are an invasive species, and as such are prohibited in some European countries and Australia.

20 Rock Monitors (CITES II), 22 senegalese chameleons (CITES II), crested chameleon (CITES II), graceful chameleon (CITES II), 34 Bell's hinged tortoises (CITES II), 98 Home's hinge-back tortoise (CITES II). The consignment was hidden with a shipment of 526 lizards that were legal for import.
Red-eyed Leaf frogs (CITES II)
Swedish barber had thought the young crocodile was a monitor lizard
Black pond turtles (CITES I). Found in 3 unclaimed, unaddressed bags.
Black pond turtles (CITES I). One arrest. 330 turtles were stil alive upon discover.

column2: Black Pond Turtles; Crowned River Turtles; Three-keeled Land Tortoises; Indian Eyed Turtles
column15: 72 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I), 6 Crowned River Turtles (CITES II), one Three-keeled Land Tortoise (CITES I), and one Indian Eyed Turtle (CITES II). The tortoises/turtles were discovered by Royal Thai Customs officials in two unclaimed bags that began emitting a rotting smell.

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Black Pond Turtles
column15: 423 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II); 52 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I). Two unclaimed bags were suspicious for being extremely heavy. Royal Thai Customs officials waited several hours for the bags to be picked up before deciding to confiscate and scan them.
Ball pythons (CITES II). Chinese citizen was caught carrying the snakes.

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Black Pond Turtles
column15: 423 Indian Star Tortoises and 52 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I). One Pakistani national (Mustafa Ali) was arrested with four suitcases on arrival in Bangkok from Lahore on Thai Airways International flight TG346. Royal Thai Customs facilitated this seizure. One source mentions that the turtles were discovered when two of unclaimed suitcases were opened at the airport. Unclear if this is correct.
Caimans (CITES II) were largely dead on arrival. They were packed too tightly in boxes.
48 of the 200 Caimans (CITES II) were dead after the flight from Guyana and the 3 snakes and 14 further caimans died after landing.
suspect is a 58 year-old man, said that the reptiles were for a different country but unclear which one, 35 chameleons and 54 lizards
Radiated tortoises (CITES I) were found in an unclaimed bag. One Malagasy was arrested.
Box turtles (CITES II). Hidden in double bottoms of polystyrene cases
Turtles were found wrapped inside socks in luggage of two passengers.
Included 33 Chameleons(CITES II) hidden among non-CITES species. Shipmment was targeted based on a risk assesment
Pig-nosed turtles (CITES II). There are two possible airports in West Papua, both of them tiny (1000-1300 meters)

column13: suspect didn't declare 3 smartphones so Customs did a more thorough baggage inspection
column15: The suspect is a resident of Sharon in his 40s; returning from a trip to NY; Customs looked thorugh his luggage and found 3 smartphone Nexus 5 that the individual had not declared to Customs so the Customs did a more thorough inspection; the passenger told police that the frogs are native to South America and bought them to sell later

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Black Pond Turtles
column15: 440 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) and 65 Black Pond turtles (CITES I) were found by Thai Customs officials in 5 unclaimed bags on a flight from Chennai, india.
San Salvador Rock Iguanas (CITES I), Each iguana was wrapped in a sock, and one had died in transit. Two Romanian women were arrested.
200 exotic turtles seized and Hanif Mohammed arrested. The turtles were supposed to be exported to Bangkok. Export of the seized species is banned under CITES.
10 Ploughshare Tortoises (CITES I), 127 Radiated Tortoises (CITES I), and 96 chameleons (likely CITES II). Malagasy passenger arrested. 11 tortoises and 22 chameleons had died.

column14: Packed inside sealed packages in luggage and covered by carbon/graphite papers
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). 6 arrests (Noor-ul-Ameen, Mohammed Riaz, Balamurugan, Madhan Kumar, Sait Mohideen, and Raza Mohammed). Customs officials became suspicious when scans revealed odd-shaped features in their luggage. The tortoises had been packed inside sealed pouches. The suspects claimed that they were delivering the tortoises for money.
Species not reported

column6: Johannesburg, South Africa; Abu Dhabi, UAE
column14: Wrapped in paper inside a brown bag containing Malagasy handcrafts
column15: Russian woman born in 1991 with 50 baby turtles in her luggage; belonging to a protected species

The luggage was over the 30kg weight limit which led the officials to conduct a search; Dominique Rasoanaivo is the owner of the baggage is suspected of being an accomplice of the Russian arrested in Ivato on March 4, 2014

column2: Indian Narrow-Headed Soft-Shelled Turtles; Black Pond Turtles
column15: 218 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I), 54 Indian Narrow-necked Soft-shell Turtles (CITES II). Two Indian nationals arrested, having arrived from Gaya and Varanasi. Royal Thai Customs discovered the turtles. The suspects were due to board a flight to Macau when their luggage was checked and the turtles were found. This same smuggling route is often used by religious tourists.
African-spurred Tortoises (CITES II) were destined for a UK trader. Discovered based on targeting risk assessment

column13: Customs officials detained passenger due to his suspicious behavior
column15: 460 Indian Star tortoises (CITES II) were soaking in a sleeping pill solution packed tightly. Customs officials stopped the suspect (Abdul Harish) for displaying suspicious behavior and checked his baggage for what appeared to be mangos. They found tortoises instead. The suspect had previously been listed as a "sensitive traveler" for confidential reasons.
2 Morelets Crocodiles (CITES I), 4 Green Iguanas (CITES II).

Angonokas (CITES I), Radiated Tortoises (CITES I). The animals were split between two suitcases of an Egyptian passenger traveling to east africa. The discovery was made before take off and the passenger disappeared.

Black Pond turtles (CITES I) were held in 4 bags abandoned by passengers. The bags were found unattended in the arrival area of the airport. According to their tags, the bags belonged to Hashamudd M., Dantsh Zafa, Shamsad SK, and Wasi Akram

column2: Turtles; Arboreal Alligator; Lizards Horned Vipers; Five-Keeled Spiny-Tailed Iguana
column15: Snake specimens were concealed in womens' stockings, while lizards were in cloth bags and boxes. The suspect, a Mexican national, was under investigation.
Radiated tortoises (CITES I) were found in 8 suitcases. The turtles came to the Comoros from madagascar via sailboat from Mahajanga-Anjouan.
Spectacled Caimans (CITES I). Found during a document check. Similar seizures were reported from French Guiana in 2013
Greek tortoises (CITES II) were brought back by a German man in a cardboard box. The turtles originated in either Morocco or Algeria.
The animals were in the backpack and carry on of the German passenger who was deported.
The animals were also found with more than 5000 insects. The animals were confiscated
Black-breasted leaf turtles and two eggs (CITES II). The turtles were in bad shape when discovered.
One arrest. The reptiles were carried in 6 bags and were wrapped in cloth.
Two shipments of endangered Indonesian species; 97 Burmese pythons, two cockatoos, an orangutan, 3 gibbons (Java), four siamongs, loris, 144 animals total; at least 13 dead; arrested the suspects

58 Spotted Pond Turtles (CITES I) (mistakenly named Star Tortoises in media) found in 58 black duffel bag. CISF guards discovered several crawling objects inside the bag when it was scanned. suspect (Mohammed Sharif) said that he had been "let on" by a large ring of wildlife traffickers who have been operating for the past few years.

column2: Boa Constrictors; Geckos; Lizards; Royal Pythons
column7: Guanajuato, Mexico; Guadalajara, Mexico; Mexicali, Mexico
column15: Boa constrictor (CITES II), 3 geckos, 2 lizards, 2 royal pythons (CITES II), were found in four separate packages, with three different origins and three different destinations. The animals were in good condition
Common Box Turtle (CITES II)

column13: CISF personnel noticed something moving in a bag and stopped its owner
column15: Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) were concealed under clothing in a bag. CISF personnel noticed movement in the bag and arrested the Indian national (Zakir Hussain, 28) carrying it. Hussain claimed that he was innocent, but officials suspected he was part of a larger North Indian smuggling network. Hussain had said that he was given the suitcase at the airport by a man who paid him Rs. 10,000
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). Officials arrested the man who the luggage belonged to, "Thilakar, of Tondiarpet" (35).
One arrest
Turtles hidden in a soapbox.

column2: Black Pond Turtles; Indian Roof Turtles
column15: 358 Black Pond turtles (CITES I), 266 Indian roofed turtles (CITES I)

column14: Inside a diaper, wrapped with tape, and inside a videogame console
column15: Guadalajara Airport Customs discovered one Carolina Terrapin (CITES II) inside a diaper, wrapped with tape, inside a videogame console. Profepa inspected the specimen and found that the turtle didn't have documentation to prove its providence or a CITES permit. Profepa then raised a criminal complaint against a courier and parcel company for trying to export the turtle illegally to Hong Kong.
184 frogs, 42 lizards, 9 snakes, 203 tadpoles were all in plastic food containers stuffed with leaves in German passenger's baggage. Passenger was deported.
Airport in Karachi, Pakistan was also involved. Unclear if the turtles originated there or were destined for Karachi.

column14: In cloth bags, cushioned with "wet foam", inside two suitcases
column15: Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) were discovered in the passenger's luggage after boarding the flight for Bangkok. The suspect (Sajid) had arrived in Karachi from Lahore the day before. The turtles were found inside two suitcases in cloth bags cushioned with "wet foam". The passenger was taken into custody after he had already boarded the flight, and one turtle had died, although an additional 44 later died from suffocation and injuries caused during transport. The suspect claimed the shipment was ordered by an official from the Pakistani embassy in Bangkok. According to one source, the Pakistani Wildlife Department "lacks a proper place to keep suspects till they are produced in courts and has no sanctuary to lodge confiscated wild animals till they are released into their habitat. The police officers make different excuses to avoid keeping suspects in custody, though we request them in writing and its their official duty to do so, said a senior wildlife official."

column2: Diamondback Terrapins; Albino Florida Turtles; Chinese Red-Necked Turtles; Blandings Turtles; Wood Turtles
column15: 700 diamond back terrapins (CITES II), 16 Chinese Red-necked turtles(CITES II), wood turtles(CITES II), blanding turtles (CITES II). The turtles were concealed in snow boots and cereal boxes, and were being carried by a courier working for a Canadian citizen who had a recent arrest for wildlife trafficking. Two arrests. The two had worked together extensively.

column2: Reptiles; Amphibians; Tadpoles; Boa Constrictor; Glass Frogs
column15: Boa constrictor (CITES II). German tourist packed the animals into plastic boxes. Most animals were already dead.
Radiated tortoises (CITES I) were found with 8 lizards. All were found alive.

Thai Customs officials seized 669 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I). The turtles were found inside the eight suitcases of four Bangladeshi passengers upon their arrival in Bangkok from Dhaka. The suspects initially evaded arrest, but one day later, Suvarnabhumi Airport authorities arrested three men for smuggling turtles for a wildlife trafficking gang (Pongsak Puyapan, Wanas Hatawiset, and Pariwat Hannarong). All three worked as porters for a contracting company. They initially denied involvement, but eventually admitted that they were paid 500 baht each to deliver the suitcases to someone in the airport parking lot.

column14: False bottom of crates filled with sea cucumbers
column15: Radiated tortoises (CITES I) were discovered in 6 crates, 15 died shortly after being discovered.
Indian narrow-headed soft-shelled Turtles (CITES I/II). Authorities acted on a tip-off and searched a bag(s) that had been abandoned near Gate 1 in the heavy baggage gate area of the airport.
Common Water monitors (CITES II) were held in a briefcase as gifts for friends.
Pig-nosed Turtles (CITES II) hidden in a shipment of shellfish
Pig-nosed turtles (CITES II)
Black Pond Turtles (CITES I). The turtles came from india, and all turtles either died in transport or were put down. The three pieces of luggage were lined with diapers and clothes. One arrest.
Monitor Lizards (CITES I/II)
Pig-nosed Turtles (CITES I) were discovered inside 10 containers labelled as mangrove crabs.
Pig-nosed Turtles (CITES I) were found in boxes and luggage. Three people were detained.

The animals were concealed in Various manner including hollowed out books and cigarette packets. Among the lizards were skinks, geckos, frogs and pygmy pythons. 33 of the reptiles were dead when they were intercepted. Two Russian citizes and two Czech citizens were arrested, and two of the men were allegedly carrying reptiles in their luggage at the time of their arrest.
The geckos were found with 20 butterflies, and sticks partially made of pangolin scales with falsified CITES documents. The species came from Tanzania, thailand and india.
Pig-nosed Turtles (CITES II). Two arrests.
2 Kuwaitis arrested after importing species from Europe

column14: Concealed in Various pieces of cloth and kept in five stroller bags
column15: 492 Black pond turtles (CITES I) were being carried by 5 passengers who were caught and arrested at the gate by officers of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) and Customs Air Intelligence Unit (AIU). The turtles had been hidden in "Various pieces of cloth" and were stored in five stroller bags that were being carried by the suspects (Ahmed Kabir, 46, Ahmed Badhusha Marika, 40, Mohammad Salim, 28, Sayed Ahmed, 58, and Mohammed Iqbal, 42). The suspects' cell phones and passports were also seized. The accused admitted that they had received the turtles in Tiruchi and were transporting them for Rs. 10,000 each.

A joint team of WCCU, Customs, and Armed Police Battalion (APBn) seized 113 tortoises from two Indian nationals after conducting a raid near Gate No. 6 around 10 pm. The tortoises were found in four bags.

column2: Turquoise Dwarf Geckos; Bearded Pygmy Chameleons; Peacock Tree Frogs; Whip Scorpions; Yellow Headed Geckos
column15: One arrest was made in connection with the shipment.

column2: Asian Brown Pond Turtles; Japanese Pond Turtles
column15: Japanese pond turtles (CITES II) and Asian brown pond turtles were wrapped in socks, belly to belly.
Crocodiles (CITES I/II)
Nile crocodile (CITES I/II). One arrest. The skin was intended for the suspect's mother.

55 snakes,
2 baby crocodiles (CITES I/II),
35 lizards, 7 turtles, also found: 6 lemurs, 2 apes, one leopard cub. One arrest. All animals survived the trip except the baby crocodiles. The animals were packed in mini-cages, plastic boxes and bags.

9 Radiated Tortoises (CITES I), 2 Spider tortoises (CITES I), were found in the luggage of a Taiwanese couple disguised with charging wires. They bribed a local wildlife guide to steal the animals from a local breeding and rehabilitation center.

183 turtles (45 Spotted Black Terrapins - Black Pond Turtles, CITES I) were found by Customs wrapped in tape and packaged in two suitcases. Two suspects, Saiyed Ibrahim Sickender and Sahajan Naina Mohammad, were trying to smuggle the turtles to Kuala Lumpur in their check-in luggage. At least two of the turtles later died.

504 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) seized by the Punjab Wildlife Department on their way to Bangkok and two suspects arrested. The suspects had come from Karachi, and had been told they were carrying seafood items. The suspects were fined Rs. 300,000.

The Customs department at Cochin Airport in Kerala seized 29 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) from Mohammad Beeran (52). Beeran was on his way to Kuala Lumpur. The turtles were found in his check-in baggage and had been sedated. Beeran claimed he was innocent and had been tricked into smuggling the turtles.

161 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) were discovered in two cardboard cartons destined for Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Two men (Thimmarayappa Jnanamurthy and Ramaswamy Shanmugan) were arrested. They were attempting to smuggle the turtles in their check-in luggage.

column2: Asian Brown Pond Turtles; Japanese Pond Turtles
column15: Asian Brown Pond Turtles (CITES II). Japanese Pond Turtles (CITES II) Turtles were bundled belly to belly and stuffed in socks. Two arrests

column14: Wrapped in cloth and plastic in a suitcase(s)
column15: 130 Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) were seized by the Customs Intelligence Department on a tip off. Turtles became the property of the Bangladesh Forest Department and were taken to Bangabandhu Safari Park in Gazipur. No arrests.
Radiated Tortoises (CITES I) were found in the luggage of an Egyptian passenger.

column2: Russell's Vipers; Chochin Forest Cane Turtles; Chameleons
column15: Cochin Forest Cane Turtle (CITES II). Two Japanese suspects arrested. Theyboth worked in a Japanese supermarket and took footage that they intended to sell to japanese TV networks

column14: Wrapped in cloth bags placed in 8 suitcases
column15: The Egyptian national had arrived in Antananarivo 48 hours earlier; suspicions were aroused by the short duration of the stay; the police think the suspect hoped to get easily out of Malagasy territory during the strike of the Air Madagascar employees which was disrupting the operation of the airport

column14: Covered in cardboard and pillow covers in two suitcases
column15: Black pond turtles (CITES I) in two black suitcases. Central Industrial Security Forces (CISF) officials noticed movement in the suitcase through the scanner. The officials opened the suitcases and found the turtles covered in cardboard and pillow covers, with their legs taped together. The Two suspects (Haroon Rashid and Mohammed Ali, alias Imran Khan) caught. They claimed that their contact in Chennai had asked them to take the turtles to someone in Phuket, Thailand. They had been given Rs. 10,000 and free tickets to hand over the bags. Due to increased surveillance at Chennai Airport, traffickers left from Bangalore. The turtles had traveled from Calcutta to Chennai via boat. An investigation was begun to find the duo's contact in Chennai.

54 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) from Malaysia-bound passenger. Customs officials saw movement in the baggage scan, opened the bags and found the turtles. The suspect (Mohammad Ali, 45) said he was staying in a hotel in Chennai, and had been approached by two people at the airport to deliver the bag containing the turtles to a contact in Kuala Lumpur for Rs. 3000.
Mangrove Monitor Lizards (CITES II). The lizards were recoverd alive.
60 or 64 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). Naina Mohammed Yasin was arrested by Customs officials.
One arrest

Black pond turtles (CITES I). The shipping company was Mamun International. A company under the same name is based in Nagpur, Maharashtra which specializes in manufacturing plastic products. The turtles were packed into 53 plastic containers. One arrest.

41 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). A CISF official noticed small objects moving within the luggage of Saddam Hussain (25). The official alerted Customs officers, who found 41 tortoises inside. This seizure prompted the Forest Department to begin investigating all the cases of turtle trafficking from Chennai to Kuala Lumpur to see if they were linked. From the article on the seizure: "There are usually 10-12 seizures every year where protected animals are found in passengers bags, satchels and even belts which are then handed over to the forest department, with the majority of  the seizures being star tortoises, followed by sea-horses....SMUGGLING ROUTE: The major smuggling points for star tortoises are from Bengal, Odisha, Andhra Pradesh and coastal Tamil Nadu
LOADED LUGGAGE: Star tortoises can be kept in confined places like suitcases and taken for long journeys without any harm done to them for up to 4-6 hours"
Black Pond Turtles (CITES I) 27 of the turtles died after being found. 2 Russian nationals were arrested and sentenced.
100 or 130 Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) and two people (Suleiman Mohammad and Leila Banu) were arrested. Officials found the tortoises in their luggage during the baggage scan.
Black Pond turtles (CITES I) were packed into 5 bags. The bag carriers fled.
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II)
Black pond turtles (CITES I) One arrest of an Indian street vendor.
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). One arrest

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; Black Pond Turtles
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II), Black Pond Turtles (CITES I). Two arrests, both smugglers were from Chennai, India. Their tickets were paid for by the 'network head' and were to recieve $150 bonuses.
Radiated Tortoises (CITES I). Two arrests. An airport employee reprotedly assisted the pair in clearing Customs.

column2: Indian Star Tortoises; spotted black terrapins
column15: Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) Spotted Black Terrapins (CITES I) Two arrests. The animals had been taped to restrict movement. They had traveled from Chennai and were bound for Kuala Lumpur. Apparently, the duo had been enticed by an offer of payment and a free flight to Malaysia in exchange for carrying the luggage.
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). One arrest
Reticulated Python (CITES II) One arrest of a Chinese national
Crocodile (CITES I/II)
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II) One arrest.
Black spotted Turtles (CITES I) were discovered being smuggled by a Pakistani man with previous wildlife smuggling charges.

column14: Hidden in socks/stockings in diapers in two wood crates
column15: 8 Ploughshare Tortoises (CITES I), 763 Radiated Tortoises (CITES I). 20 Radiated tortoises died afterwards. The turtles were hidden in socks/stockings in diapers and undeclared in two wooden crates bound for Kuala Lumpur.
Indian Star tortoises (CITES II). One arrest. The suspect had already been implicated in ketamine smuggling.
Black Pond turtles (CITES I)
Indian star tortoises (CITES II). Two arrests. The organizer of the smuggling attemped was identified as Dinesh Jothimani. This was the fourth seizure where the smugglers named him as the organizers.
Indian Star Tortoises (CITES II). One arrest
Earless Monitor Lizards (Unlisted but likely will qualify for CITES I). German citizen involved
Green Iguanas (CITES II).
Radiated Tortoises (CITES I) were wrapped in baby diapers and in socks to absorb excrement and prevent movement. A chinese citizen was carrying the suitcases. 25 turtles died
Radiated tortoises (CITES I) were grouped in by 3's and 6's in socks with sanitary napkins. Arrest of 2 tanzanians.

column2: Black Pond Turtles; South Asian Box Turtles; pig-nosed Turtles; Asian Leaf Turtles; Red-Bellied Short-Necked Turtle
column15: Black Pond Turtles (CITES I), South Asian Box Turtles (CITES II), Asian Leaf Turtles(CITES II), Pig-nosed turtles (CITES II). The turtles arrived in a shipment labeled as crabs
Radiated Tortoises (CITES I) were packed into 4 suitcases. Only 7 died in transit. 1 Arrest of a chinese national.
Black Spotted Turtles (CITES I) were found sedated in a crockery consignment in early 2016
Indian traveler was carrying the turtles
Ten of the animals were dead.

column2: Monitor Lizards; sailfin lizards; rat snakes; water snakes
column15: 11 monitor lizards (CITES II), 8 sailfin lizards, 6 water snakes, 5 rat snakes. One airport employee was arrested. The shipment also included Tarsiers, Scoop owls and Eagle owls

column14: In a box that was supposed to contain crab from Indonesia
column15: Animals endangered; unclear if for pet or medicinal purposes

column2: Green Tree Pythons; Argentine Red Tegus; Indian Star Tortoises
column15: Green Tree pythons (CITES II), Argentine Red Tegu (CITES II), Indian star tortoise (CITES II) were in the posssession of a Chinese national who had purchased the animals at Pasar Pramuka, an exotic bird and animal market in Jakarta.
A Chinese national was arrested carrying the tortoises, 3,750 pakistani Rupees, $1,000, and 300 yuan
Black pond turtles (CITES I) three arrests three Malaysian airlines employees, one luggage inspector is also suspected but fled.
Pig-nosed turtles (CITES II). The turtles were packed into boxes which were placed inside 4 suitcases and brought in through an older entrance to the airport which lacks an X-ray machine.
Pig-nosed turtles (CITES II). The turtles were concealed in 38 boxes. Customs officers noticed a change in boxes that they had already inspected and reinspected.
Crocodile (CITES I/II), Python (CITES II). The luggage was being carried by a Senegalese man. The man was fined 30,000 Euros

551 Mata Mata Turtles were discovered in a shipment at the Alfredo Vsquez airport in Colombia. A number of the turtles had died and were sent off for DNA analysis to identify their origin. They were linked to a species that lives in Puerto Carreo. The shipment was likely destined for the USA through Central America.
Chameleons (CITES I/II) and Geckos (CITES II). The luggage belonged to a Russian national.
Green Tree pythons (CITES II) were seized from the luggage of 2 Malay nationals.

Black Spotted Turtles (CITES I); Black pond turtles (CITES I) were captured in Lahore according too the trafficker based in Karachi. One arrest. The trafficker is an exporter of dried fish and canned vegetables.
The suspect is a man and Cote d'Ivoire national about 50 years old, said he was a collector and the items were for personal use; all these endangered species are protected under CITES

Ploughshare Tortoises (CITES I) Radiated Tortoises (CITES I). Traveller continued onto Kathmandu, Nepal, leaving the bag behind.The bag went undiscovered for a week, during which time two of the 139 radiated tortoises died.
Total of 6 bags filled with cobras found; they were in 2 polystyrene boxes with ice to limit the movement of snakes, whose mouths were sutured with surgical thread

column2: Abronia Arboreal Alligator Lizards; milk snakes
column15: Shipper was located in Nezahualcoyotl, State of Mexico.

column2: Pyxis Tortoises; Ploughshare Tortoises; Radiated Tortoises
column15: Subject denied containing the tortoises, subject of a deportation order

Turtles were hidden in two bags back-to-back, with a layer of plastic film between them all so they couldn't move; suspect was a Malagasy national, he fled, abandoning his luggage (unclear as to why); authorities know the name of the fugitive; subject is named Clement A

Mohamed Habib, a native of Ramanathapuram, tried to smuggle in the tortoises in his suitcase. Around 4,000 tortoises, all sized about one inch each, were dumped in a suitcase two feet in length and one and half feet in breadth. The passenger tried to smuggle the tortoises from Malaysia, said an official. The officer also said that the man tried to smuggle the same species of tortoises 26 days ago, but his attempt had failed.
